diagrams.description: Electrical engineering's foundations began in the 1600s with William Gilbert's studies of electricity and magnetism. The 1800s marked rapid advancement: Alessandro Volta invented the battery (1800), Michael Faraday discovered electromagnetic induction (1831), and James Clerk Maxwell formulated electromagnetic theory (1865). 1879 brought Edison's practical incandescent light bulb. The 1880s saw the War of Currents between Edison's DC and Tesla's AC systems, with AC ultimately prevailing. 1888 introduced Nikola Tesla's induction motor and transformer innovations. The early 1900s established power grids and long-distance transmission. 1947 witnessed the transistor invention, bridging electrical and electronics. The 1960s-70s brought integrated circuits and digital systems. The 1980s-90s saw power electronics advancement and renewable energy integration. The 2000s-2020s continue with smart grids, energy storage systems, electric vehicles, and sustainable power solutions becoming mainstream.
diagrams.mermaid_code: timeline title Electrical Engineering Evolution section Early Foundations 1600s : William Gilbert's studies : Electricity & magnetism 1800 : Volta invents battery 1831 : Faraday's electromagnetic induction 1865 : Maxwell's electromagnetic theory section Power Era Birth 1879 : Edison's incandescent bulb 1880s : War of Currents (AC vs DC) : AC system prevails 1888 : Tesla's induction motor : Transformer innovations section Grid Development Early 1900s : Power grids established : Long-distance transmission 1947 : Transistor invented : Electronics bridge section Digital Revolution 1960s-70s : Integrated circuits : Digital systems emerge 1980s-90s : Power electronics advances : Renewable integration begins section Modern Era 2000s-2020s : Smart grids : Energy storage systems : Electric vehicles : Sustainable power solutions
